questions.text: Forensic Medicine deals with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Forensic medicinedeals with the application of medical knowledge into the processes of Law, both Civil and Criminal.
    In short, it deals with Medical aspects of Law.
  • Medical jurisprudencedeals with the application of knowledge of Law in the practice of Medicine.
    In short, it deals with the Legal aspects of Medicine. (Option B ruled out)
  • Medical ethicsdeals with the moral principles that should guide members of the medical profession in their interactions with one another, their patients, and the state.
    That means it includes
    • Doctor-Doctor relationship
    • Doctor-Patient relationship
    • Doctor-State relationship (Option C ruled out)
  • Medical etiquettedeals with the conventional laws of courtesy to be observed between members of the medical profession (Doctor - Doctor Relationship).[Option D ruled out]

questions.text: Mens rea means
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mens rea: Guilty mind
  • Actus rea: Guilty act
  • Mutatis Mutandis: The necessary changes having been made (Option B ruled out)
  • Pari Passu: Equal in all respects (Option C ruled out)
  • Ultra Vires: Beyond the power/authority/scope (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: The enquiry into the circumstances of death is called
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Inquest means an enquiry into the causes of death, which is not due to natural causes.

Explanation of other options:-

Corpus delicti (Option B) means "Body of offence" or "essence of crime"; it means the facts (elements) of any criminal offence, e.g. murder.

A verdict (Option C) is a decision on an issue of fact in a civil or criminal case or an inquest.

Open verdict (Option D)  means an announcement of the commission of a crime without information regarding the accused.

questions.text: A subpoena is a kind of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sub = Under, Poena = Penalty.
  • Subpoena means summons.
  • It is a written document issued by the court and served to the witness. Under a penalty in all cases to attend the court of law for giving evidence on a particular day and time.
  • It is not a designation or decomposed body tissue. (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Courts are established to maintain law and order in the respective jurisdiction. On the contrary, tribunals are a part of the judicial set-up that deals with direct taxes, labour, cooperatives, claims for accidents, etc. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: If a lady dies of an unnatural and suspicious death within 7 years of her marriage, the inquest will be conducted by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 80 BNS - Dowry death -Where the death of a woman is caused by any  burns or bodily injury or occurs otherwise than under normal circumstances within seven years of her marriage and it is shown that soon before her death she was subjected to cruelty or harassment by her husband or any relative of her husband for, or in connection with, any demand for dowry, such death shall be called "dowry death", and such husband or relative shall be deemed to have caused her death.
  • Whoever commits dowry death shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than seven years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life.
  • And in case of dowry death, the magistrate has to hold an Inquest and not by the police.

Explanation of other options:

Deputy Superintendent of Police (Option A): Not authorised under law to conduct inquests in dowry death cases.

Forensic medical expert (Option B): Can assist in the examination but has no legal authority to conduct an inquest.

Coroner (Option C): The Coroner's system has been abolished in India. It existed earlier only in Mumbai but is no longer in use.

questions.text: Who can be considered an expert witness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A common/Ordinary Witness is a person who gives evidence about the facts observed by them.
  • An Expert Witness is qualified or experienced in a scientific or technical subject and is capable of giving an opinion from the facts observed by himself or others,g. Doctor, a fingerprint expert, a handwriting expert, a firearm expert, etc.
  • Sec. 39 of Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam deals with expert witnesses.
  • Sec. 39 BSA: Opinion of experts:(1) When the Court has to form an opinion upon a point of foreign law of science or art, or any other field, or as to the identity of handwriting or finger impressions, the opinions upon that point of persons specially skilled in such foreign law, science or art, or any other field, or in questions as to identity of handwriting or finger impressions are relevant facts and such persons are called experts.

questions.text: The type of inquest never followed in India is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In India, there are only two types of Inquest:
    • Police Inquest and (Option A)
    • Magistrate's inquest (Option B)
  • Previously, there was a Coroner's Inquest which was abolished. (Option C)
  • The Medical Examiner system is never held in India.

questions.text: In India, a magistrate's inquest is done in the following cases, except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In India, a Magistrate's inquest is done in cases of -
    • Death in police custody,
    • Death due to police firing,
    • Death while under police interrogation (Option D ruled out),
    • Death in prison,
    • Death of a mentally ill prisoner in a psychiatric hospital,
    • Dowry death (Option B ruled out),
    • Exhumation (Option A ruled out),
  • In case of murder, the inquest is done by the Police.

Note: Police Inquest is dealt with under Sec. 194 BNSS and Magistrate Inquest is dealt with under Sec. 196 BNSS

questions.text: The trial court for the offences committed by the children is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A juvenile offender is an offender who is less than 18 years of age (Both males and females).
  • In the case of a juvenile offender, the trial will not take place in a regular court, but in the juvenile justice board.
  • The aim of juvenile justice is reformation and rehabilitation, not punishment.
  • Children in conflict with the law are dealt with by special provisions in the Indian legal and forensic systems.

Explanation of other options:

High Court (Option A): Handles constitutional and appellate matters.

Sessions Court (Option B): Handles serious criminal offences in adults.

Magistrate Court (Option C): Handles minor criminal cases.

questions.text: A doctor is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A common witness (also called an ordinary witness) testifies about facts personally observed, such as the dimensions and appearance of a wound. (Option A)
  • An expert witness, on the other hand, provides professional opinions based on specialised knowledge, for example, the type of weapon used or the nature of injuries. (Option B)
  • The Indian Medical Council Act 1956 in section 15 (2) (C) states that no person other than a medical practitioner enrolled on a state medical register shall be entitled to give evidence at any inquest or in any court of law as an expert under Sec. 39 BSA on any matter relating to medicine.

questions.text: A police officer can arrest a person without a warrant in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A cognizable offenceis an offence in which a police officer can arrest a person without a warrant from the Magistrate. Examples - Rape, murder, dowry death, ragging etc.
  • The non-cognizable offenceis an offence in which a police officer cannot arrest a person without a warrant from the Magistrate. (Option B ruled out)
  • Summons casesare offences for which imprisonment is less than 2 years (Option C ruled out)
  • Warrant casesare offences for which imprisonment is more than 2 years (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Who among the following is legally permitted to receive a dying declaration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A dying declaration is a written or oral statement made by a person on the verge of death, explaining the circumstances leading to their fatal condition — usually involving an unlawful act.
  • Ideally, a Magistrate is called to record the statement.

However, in emergencies, if the Magistrate is unavailable and the person is in a critical condition, the declaration can be recorded by:

  • A medical officer (Option A)
  • A police officer (Option C)
  • Any responsible person (e.g., a lawyer or bystander) (Option B)

The declaration must be recorded in the presence of two witnesses whenever possible.

questions.text: Re-examination of a prosecution witness will be done by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stages of Witness Examination in Court

For a prosecution witness, the sequence of examination is as follows:

  • Chief examination by the Public Prosecutor
  • Cross-examination by the Defence Lawyer
  • Re-examination by the Public Prosecutor

The purpose of re-examination is to:

  • Clarify any doubts or ambiguities raised during cross-examination
  • Correct errors or reinforce specific parts of the testimony

The Public Prosecutor thus plays a central role in initiating and concluding the witness’s examination phases from the prosecution side.

Explanation of other options:

Defence Lawyer (Option B): Only conducts cross-examination, not re-examination.

Presiding Judge (Option C): May ask questions for clarification, but does not perform formal re-examination.

Accused person (Option D): Cannot directly examine or re-examine witnesses — must do so through legal counsel.

questions.text: All of the following documents are accepted in the court without cross-examination, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exceptions to oral evidence are:

  1. Dying declaration. (Option B ruled out)
  2. The expert opinion is expressed in the
  3. Evidence of a doctor recorded in a lower court.
  4. Evidence given by a witness in a previous judicial proceeding.
  5. Evidence of Mint officer or any officer of India Security Press.
  6. Reports of certain Govt. Scientific experts, such as Chemical examiners, Chief Inspector of Explosives, Director of the Fingerprint bureau, Director of the Central Forensic Science Laboratory, serologist, (Options A and C ruled out)
  7. Public records.
  8. Hospital Records: Routine entries such as DOA, DOD, Pulse, Temperature, etc.
  9. When the certificate or document is acceptable to the counsels (lawyer of the accused) without cross-examination etc.
  • Medico-legal reports are accepted in a Court of law only after cross-examination unless the opposite lawyer is willing to accept without cross-examination.

questions.text: The first-hand knowledge rule applies to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The first-hand knowledge rule applies to a common witness who gives evidence about the facts observed or perceived by them.
  • An expert witness is someone who has been trained or is skilled or has knowledge and experience, and can conclude from the facts observed by them. Doctors, handwriting/fingerprints/firearms experts etc. come under this category. (Options B and C ruled out)
  • A hostile witness is a person who is supposed to have some interest or motive for concealing a part of the truth or for giving completely false evidence. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: The maximum punishment for issuing a false certificate to be used in any stage of a judicial proceeding is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sec. 234 BNS /IPC sec 197- Issuing or signing false certificate:Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law to be given or signed, or relating to any fact of which such certificate is by law admissible in evidence, knowing or believing that such certificate is false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.
  • Sec. 229 BNS - Punishment for false evidence:(1) Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence to be used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees. (2) Whoever intentionally gives or fabricates false evidence in any case other than that referred to in subsection (1) shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term that may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to a fine which may extend to five thousand rupees. (Options A, B and C ruled out)

questions.text: According to the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, Section 39 gives information regarding:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Section 39 BSA (Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam) gives information regarding Expert witnesses.

 39 BSA: (1) When the Court has to form an opinion upon a point of foreign law or of science or art, or any other field, or as to the identity of handwriting or finger impressions, the opinions upon that point of persons specially skilled in such foreign law, science or art, or any other field, or in questions as to the identity of handwriting or finger impressions are relevant facts and such persons are called experts.

(Options A, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Which Section of the BNS deals with the punishment of perjury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The punishment for perjury is dealt under Sec. 229 BNS

Perjury is defined as the offence of wilfully telling an untruth or making a misrepresentation under oath or solemn affirmation.

Important BNS sections related to false evidence and false certificates.

229 (IPC sec 193)→ Punishment for Sec. 227 and 228 BNS (Up to 7 years of imprisonment)

  • Sec. 229 BNS - Punishment for false evidence: (1) Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence to be used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees. (2) Whoever intentionally gives or fabricates false evidence in any case other than that referred to in subsection (1) shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years and shall also be liable to a fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.

Explanation of other options:

  • Sec. 227 BNS - Giving false evidence (PERJURY) (Option A):Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.
  • Sec. 228 BNS - Fabricating false evidence (Option B):Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any false entry in any book or record, or electronic record or makes any document or electronic record containing a false statement, intending that such circumstance, false entry or false statement may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding or a proceeding taken by law before a public servant as such, or before an arbitrator, and that such circumstance, false entry or false statement, so appearing in evidence, may cause any person who in such proceeding is to form an opinion upon the evidence, to entertain an erroneous opinion touching any point material to the result of such proceeding is said "to fabricate false evidence".
  • Sec. 234 BNS - Issuing or signing false certificate (Option D): Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law to be given or signed, or relating to any fact of which such certificate is by law admissible in evidence, knowing or believing that such certificate is false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence..

questions.text: In a court trial, leading questions are not permitted in all the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a court trial, leading questions are permitted during cross-examination as per Sec 146(4) BSA.

  • A leading question suggests to the witness the answer desired, or which includes a material fact and admits of a conclusive answer by a simple "Yes" or "No" [S.146(1) BSA].
  • Leading questions are permissible during cross-examination [S.146(4) BSA].
  • In the case of chief (direct) examination and re-examination, leading questions are not allowed, except in those cases where the Judge is satisfied that a witness is hostile [S.146(2) & (3) and Sec. 157 BSA]. (Options A and D ruled out).
  • The Judge can always disallow irrelevant Dying declaration: Must be recorded without prompting or suggestive questioning. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: 'A' kills 'B' with a knife. Another person, Z' saw 'A' with a knife in the park a few minutes before the murder. 'Z' gives this statement in a court of law. What kind of evidence is it?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Indirect or Circumstantial: It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness but has a bearing upon the fact of the other and subsidiary facts which are relied upon as consistent, e.g., in case of alleged murder of A by B at a certain place on a particular day and time, the circumstantial evidence would be that C saw B with a knife on that day at that place, a few minutes before the murder.
  • Circumstantial evidence requires the Court to draw logical or reasonable inferences from the information presented.

Explanation of other options:

Direct (Option A): Evidence of a fact that is actually in issue, e.g., an electric blanket that has caused injury, a prescription, or a consent form.

Hostile (Option C): Refers to a witness who turns against the party that called them

Hearsay (Option D): It is any statement made by any person about what he did not personally witness, or evidence he obtained from a third party, which is presented in the Court to assert that the facts contained in the statement are true, e.g., A gives evidence in the witness box stating that B had informed him that he had seen C committing a crime. In such cases, direct evidence can be given only by B that he had seen C committing a crime.
